edu.calpoly.spritely

Class GraphicsWindow

  • java.lang.Object
    • edu.calpoly.spritely.AnimationWindow
      • edu.calpoly.spritely.GraphicsWindow

  • public final class GraphicsWindow
extends AnimationWindow
    A GraphicsWindow is a frame for displaying graphical animation. This is an alternate entry point for the Spritely framework. It removes the restriction of animating a grid, but it does not give the option of a text mode. It is also more complicated in some ways.

    The basic lifecycle of a GraphicsWindow application is as follows: 

        GraphicsWindow window = new GraphicsWindow(...);
    window.setXXX() (frames/second, callbacks, etc.)
    window.start();
    while (window.isRunning()) {
        update any needed data structures
        Grahpics2D g = window.waitForNextFrame();        
        if (g == null) {   // Stopped
            break;
        }
        call Graphics2D methods on g to draw frame
        window.showNextFrame();
        do anything else you want to do
        if (you're done with window) {
            window.stop();
        }
    }
    System.exit(0);
    You are not required to have a single "event loop" like this, however. You can call frame.waitForNextFrame() and frame.showFrame() whenever you want to within your program, as long as you don't try to call it from a mouse or keyboard handler. It will only call your callbacks during a call to showNextFrame(), so you don't need to handle multi-threading.

    This style of animation creates a new frame, some number of times per second (controlled by the frames/second value you set). This frees you from having to track if things have changed; you just fill up a frame object with the current state of the world every time the framework is ready for you. Don't worry too much about wasting CPU time. This kind of animation is usually done on a personal computer, where you have CPU power to burn. Also, in a real program that features motion, something usually changes every frame anyway. If you really want to optimize painting, check out paintLastFrameTo(java.awt.Graphics2D).

    It's expected that you won't have multiple windows, but you can. You can run each window from its own thread, or you can arrange to call showNextFrame on the multiple frame objects, one after the other, from the same thread.

    This framework can also be used when animation isn't continuous, e.g. in turn-based games. In this case, fps gives a maximum number of frames/second, which might be useful for periods when there is no user input. In this case, calling pauseAnimation(0) before waitForNextFrame() will reset the animation clock.

    • Constructor Detail

      • GraphicsWindow

        public GraphicsWindow(java.lang.String name,
                      Size canvasSize)
        Initialize a GraphicsWindow to represent a canvas canvasSize.width pixels wide and canvasSize.height pixels high.
        Parameters:
        name - The name of this window. This might be shown in the title area of the screen.
        canvasSize - The pixel size of the grid that is to be animated.
        See Also:
        AnimationWindow.setFps(double), AnimationWindow.setKeyTypedHandler(KeyTypedHandler), AnimationWindow.setMouseClickedHandler(MouseClickedHandler)

    • Method Detail

      • getCanvasSize

        public Size getCanvasSize()
        Get the size of the canvas we're animating.
        Returns:
        the size

      • getInitialFrame

        public java.awt.Graphics2D getInitialFrame()
        Get a Graphics to set up the initial screen, before start() is called. This is entirely optional, but it might help to avoid a flashing effect when a window is created.
        Returns:
        A graphics context where client code can draw the initial screen. The framework will call dispose() on this graphics when the frame is shown.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we've started, or this has been called before.

      • start

        public void start()
        Start this SpriteWindow. If our environment is graphics-capable, this will create a window where the graphics are displayed. This may only be called once per SpriteWindow.
        Overrides:
        start in class AnimationWindow
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if we were already started

      • waitForNextFrame

        public java.awt.Graphics2D waitForNextFrame()
        Wait for the next frame of animation. Returns null if this window is stopped. If the current thread is interrupted, the window will be stopped.
        Returns:
        A graphics where client code can draw the next frame of animation.

      • paintLastFrameTo

        public void paintLastFrameTo(java.awt.Graphics2D g)
        Paint the last frame of animation to the given graphics. This can be a useful optimization if only a small part of the frame has changed.
        Parameters:
        g - A graphics obtained from waitForNextFrame()
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()

      • showNextFrame

        public void showNextFrame()
        Show the next frame of animation. The drawing done to the graphics returned by last returned AnimationFrame last returned by waitForNextFrame is displayed to the screen.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if waitForNextFrame() has not been called, or if start has not been called, or if the animation has been stopped.
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame(), showNextFrame(boolean)

      • showNextFrame

        public void showNextFrame(boolean drawingWasDone)
        Show the next frame of animation. The drawing done to the graphics last returned by waitForNextFrame is displayed to the screen. If this frame is identical to the previous frame, the caller should pass false for drawingWasDone. In this case, no drawing should have been done to the graphics; any such drawing will be ignored.
        Parameters:
        drawingWasDone - Flag do indicate if this frame changes anything relative to the last frame.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalStateException - if waitForNextFrame() has not been called, or if start has not been called, or if the animation has been stopped.
        See Also:
        waitForNextFrame()
